Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> I'm surprised no one is talking about the merged mining too, that's no small feat. Consider how mining profitability has become an issue lately and how some miners jump ship every day in search of something else. Now consider mining Verus and while you're at it, mining several other projects at the same time at no additional cost to the miner. Seems like a no brainer choice and eventually with PBaaS projects growing by choosing to be on the most advanced/secure network and miners having options, Verus can become it's own micro-economy that would offer miners/stakers and project developers an alternative that would be very hard to compete with.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> Dot get me wrong, but the way I see it is pBaaS  a form of merged mining, since Verus will be the main chain and any pBaaS chain will be an auxiliary chain.... or do I look at it completely wrong?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Well you'd think that, since they go together so well and it's such an elegant answer to many problems for both but look at Ethereum, if you build crypto kitties on them you gunk down everyone else on the network, with this each chain is independent.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> If you use the asset functionality on RVN you still have to mine RVN and depend on them rather than mine your own project

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Basically what this means is say you take Bitcoin and how it uses sha256, now if you had another project that runs on sha256 and merged mining was possible, you could mine BTC and the hashes you submit will have a chance to win the reward for btc and have the chance to hit for the other coin at the same time so this is something very different. Picture mining VRSC and hitting a block for them but also earning rewards for other projects just as if you were mining them.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> .
This is an excerpt from something I found online:
Merged mining works like this, you have two totally separate block chains, they are not related in any way nor does either contain any data from the other. When you mine you generate hashes that may be the solution to the current block, this is very very improbable per hash, its like a lottery where everyone generates tickets until someone finds the winning one. Normally you make tickets and check them against the Bitcoin block chain to see if they are the solution. With merged mining you create a ticket and check it against both the Bitcoin block chain and the other block chain, Bitcoin and the other chain know nothing about each other, they are two totally different lotteries with different winning numbers, you just sent a copy of your ticket to both. Since you are sending the same ticket to two lotteries you increase your chances of winning one or the other. No Bitcoin data goes into the other and none of the other coin's data goes into Bitcoin they remain totally separate, you simply run both the other coin's and Bitcoin clients on the same machine and submit hashes to both networks, if your hash is the solution to the other coin's block you get it's reward, if you hash is the solution to the Bitcoin block you get Bitcoins, its exactly like if you were mining on just one network, except you submit the same work twice."

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> That in conjunction with PBaaS AND this new merkle mountain range solution that may rival mimblewimble's blockchain shrinking abilities.. Verus is very technically impressive already but it's really shaping up to be something truly special.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Oink> Yes, I had read all that info and compared it (in my head) with the way pBaaS is structured. Instead of continuously making a chance on both chains, the auxilairy pBaaS chain isn’t in continuous contact with the main chain: a far more efficient way to lighten the load on the main chain, which is a huge pro, IMHO.
My main reservation on merged mining is that big mining farms will simultaneously gain more control over several chains. Decentralization is at peril, which is IMHO an unwanted scenario.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Well fortunately VerusHash 2.0 was designed to help prevent this by spreading the hash and as more and more jump on I'm sure more people with CPUs will become aware and join in

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> True. On the other hand: Merge mining will decrease the footprint mining has on our global energy consumption. (f*ck*ng autocorrect...)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> It shouldn't have any more of a centralizing effect than say ethereum and its erc projects

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> That's another huge benefit! On top of the CPU friendly nature of VerusHash 2.0 being energy efficient the 50%PoS is a big deal and now merged mining is another huge step towards reducing that footprint

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> So many angles covered it blows my mind to think how well they all compliment each other

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> I don’t agree. Since a miner is simultaneously mining multiple chains, profitability goes up. Incentive for our cheap electricity areas to focus on those merged mining projects, which in turn centralizes mining to those areas.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> Then again, if Verus would act as the main chain, the present community could aid upcoming chains/coins.
